tn.ref: When Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no children
tn.text: "When Rachel realized that she was unable to become preganant"
Rachel is using hyperbole to show how upset she is about not having children. AT: "I will feel completely worthless" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
"Cause me to become pregnant"
Jacob's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire. AT: "Jacob was very angry with Rachel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Am I in the place of God, who has kept you from having children?
tn.text: This is a rhetorical question that Jacob uses to scold Rachel. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am not God! I am not the one who is preventing you from having children!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Rachel said"
"Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you." This adds emphasis to what Rachel says next.

tn.ref: there is my servant Bilhah ... I will have children by her
tn.text: At that time, this was an acceptable way for a barren woman to have children that would legally belong to her. The full meaning of this may be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is the name of Rachel's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:28|29:29]].
This is a way of saying that the child that Bilhah gives birth to will belong to Rachel. AT: "for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: I will have children by her
tn.text: "and in this way she will cause me to have children"
This is the name of Rachel's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:28|29:29]].
"gave birth to a son for Jacob"
"Rachel gave him the name"
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Dan means 'he judged.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Bilhah ... became pregnant again"

tn.ref: and bore Jacob a second son
tn.text: "and gave birth to a second son for Jacob"

tn.ref: With mighty wrestlings have I wrestled with my sister
tn.text: The phrase "wrestlings have I wrestled" is an idiom used for emphasis. It is also a metaphor that speaks of Rachel's attempts to have a child like her sister as if she were having a physical fight with Leah. AT: "I have had a great struggle to have children like my older sister, Leah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"and I have won" or "I have succeeded"
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Naphtali means 'my struggle.'"
"When Leah became aware that"

tn.ref: she took Zilpah, her servant, and gave her to Jacob as a wife
tn.text: "she gave Zilpah, her servant, to Jacob as a wife"
This is the name of Leah's female servant. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:23|29:24]].
"gave birth to a son for Jacob"
"How fortunate!" or "What good luck!"
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Gad means 'fortunate.'"
This is the name of Leah's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:23|29:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"gave birth to a second son for Jacob"
"How blessed I am!" or "How happy I am!"
"the women" or "the young women"
Translators may also add a footnote that says "The name Asher means 'happy.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Reuben went out"

tn.ref: in the days of wheat harvest
tn.text: Here the phrase "in the days of" is an idiom that refers to the season or time of year. AT: "at the time of year of the wheat harvest" or "during the wheat harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a fruit that was said to increase fertility and the desire to sleep with one's lover. AT: "love fruit" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: Is it a small matter to you ... my husband?
tn.text: "Do you not care ... my husband?" This is a rhetorical question used to scold Rachel. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "It is bad enough ... my husband." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a rhetorical question, used to scold Rachel. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Now you want ... too!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Then Jacob will sleep" or "Then I will let Jacob sleep"
"for the price of my son's mandrakes." See how you translated "mandrake" in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:30:14|30:14]].
"She became pregnant"

tn.ref: and bore Jacob a fifth son
tn.text: "and gave birth to a fifth son for Jacob"

tn.ref: God has given me my wages
tn.text: God rewarding Leah is spoken of as if he were a boss paying wages to someone who works for him. AT: "God has given my due" or "God has rewarded me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Translators may also add a footnote that says: "The name Issachar means 'there is a reward.'"
"Leah became pregnant again"

tn.ref: and bore a sixth son to Jacob
tn.text: "and gave birth to a sixth son for Jacob"
Translators may also add a footnote that says: "The name Zebulun means 'honor.'"
This is the name of Leah's daughter. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: God called Rachel to mind and listened to her
tn.text: The phrase "call to mind" means to remember. This does not mean God forgot about Rachel. It means he considered her request. AT: "God considered Rachel and granted to her what she wanted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: God has taken away my shame
tn.text: God causing Rachel to no longer feel ashamed is spoken of as if "shame" were an object that person could take away from someone else. The abstract noun "shame" can be stated as "ashamed." AT: "God has caused me to no longer feel ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Translators may also add a footnote that says: "The name Joseph means 'may he add.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Yahweh has added to me another son
tn.text: Rachel's first sons were through her female servant Bilhah.
"After Rachel gave birth to Joseph"
"so I can go"

tn.ref: you know the service I have given you
tn.text: Jacob is reminding Laban of their contract ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:26|Gen 29:27]]). The abstract noun "service" can be stated as "served." AT: "you know that I have served you long enough" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Laban said to Jacob"

tn.ref: If now I have found favor in your eyes
tn.text: The phrase "in your eyes" is a metonymy that represents Jacob's thoughts or opinion.  AT: "If I have found favor with you" or "If you are pleased with me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is an idiom that means that someone is approved of by someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"please stay, because"

tn.ref: I have learned by using divination
tn.text: "I have discovered by my own spiritual and magical practices"
"because of you"
This can be made more explicit. AT: "Tell me how much I have to pay to keep you here" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Jacob said to Laban"

tn.ref: how your livestock have fared with me
tn.text: "how well your livestock have done since I started taking care of them"

tn.ref: For you had little before I came
tn.text: "your herds were small before I worked for you"
"but now your wealth has greatly increased"

tn.ref: Now when will I provide for my own household also?
tn.text: "Now when will I take care of my own family?" Jacob uses a question to emphasize that he wants to start providing for his own family. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Now I want to take care of my family!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"What can I pay you" or "What can I give you." This can be made more explicit. AT: "What can I pay you so that you stay and work for me" (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]]).

tn.ref: If you will do this thing for me
tn.text: The connecting word "but" can be added to indicate that this is the one thing Jacob wants. AT: "But if you will do this thing for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])

tn.ref: feed your flock and keep it
tn.text: "feed and take care of your flock"

tn.ref: removing from it every speckled and spotted sheep, and every black one among the sheep, and the spotted and speckled among the goats
tn.text: "and remove every sheep with spots, every black sheep, and every goat with spots"
"This will be the cost of keeping me here"

tn.ref: My integrity will testify for me later on
tn.text: The word "integrity" means "honesty." This speaks about integrity as if it were a person who could testify for or against another person. AT: "And later you will know if I have been honest with you or not" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats, and black among the sheep, if any are found with me, will be considered to be stolen
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "If you find any goats without spots or any sheep that are not black, you can consider them stolen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Let it be according to your word
tn.text: Here "word" stands for something said. AT: "It will be as you say" or "We will do what you have said" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"that had stripes and spots"
"that had spots"

tn.ref: every one that had white in it
tn.text: "every goat that had some white in it"

tn.ref: and all the black ones among the sheep
tn.text: "and all the black sheep"
Here "hand" stands for control or care. AT: "had his sons take care of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are all trees with white wood. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])

tn.ref: and peeled white streaks in them, and made the white inner wood appear that was in the sticks
tn.text: "and peeled off pieces of bark so that the white wood underneath would show"
long open containers for holding water for animals to drink
"The animals of the flocks conceived" or "The animals mated"

tn.ref: produced striped, speckled, and spotted young
tn.text: "gave birth to babies with stripes and spots"
It can be made explicit that this happened over several years. AT: "During the several years following, Jacob separated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"look toward"

tn.ref: he separated out his flocks for himself alone
tn.text: "he set his flocks apart"

tn.ref: before the eyes of the flock
tn.text: Here "eyes" stands for "seeing." AT: "so that the flock could see them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"in front of the sticks"
"the weaker animals"

tn.ref: So the feebler animals were Laban's, and the stronger were Jacob's
tn.text: "So the weaker offspring belonged to Laban, while the stronger offspring belonged to Jacob." You can make this even more explicit. AT: "So the weaker offspring did not have stripes or spots and so belonged to Laban, while the stronger offspring did have stripes or spots and so belonged to Jacob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Jacob"
"greatly prospered" or "became very wealthy"
